events.summary: Jake Lang, a prominent figure from the January 6 Capitol attack, has filed a statement of candidacy with the Federal Elections Commission to run for the US Senate in Florida. Lang's campaign platform includes a "100% TRUMP AMERICA AGENDA" with priorities such as mass deportation and large tax cuts. His candidacy is part of a broader trend of January 6 participants seeking political office.

events.summary: Several Republican-controlled states, including Missouri, Texas, and Idaho, are advancing legislation to reclassify mifepristone as a controlled substance, following Louisiana's lead. In Tennessee, a proposed bill would allow lawsuits against providers of mifepristone, while Texas considers requiring in-person examinations for prescriptions. events.summary: The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) has issued a final rule revising the Wireless Emergency Alerts (WEA) system. The rule allows alert originators to send "silent alerts" without triggering the common audio attention signal or vibration cadence. This change aims to provide greater flexibility in how alerts are presented, potentially reducing alert fatigue and increasing the effectiveness of emergency communications. The rule also defines "WEA-capable mobile devices" to ensure compliance with WEA requirements. The new definitions will take effect on September 15, 2025, while the silent alert rules will become effective on March 18, 2028.
events.title: FCC Revises Wireless Emergency Alerts Rules
events.why_relevant: This rule enhances the flexibility and effectiveness of emergency alert systems, impacting public safety and communication standards.

events.summary: On March 15, 2025, President Trump signed a proclamation invoking the Alien Enemies Act of 1798 to deport alleged members of the Venezuelan gang Tren de Aragua (TdA) without due process. events.summary: A New York federal judge, Jesse Furman, has denied the Trump administration's attempt to dismiss the legal challenge brought by Mahmoud Khalil, a Palestinian activist and permanent US resident. The order also maintains that Khalil cannot be deported while his legal challenge is ongoing. Khalil's legal team argues that his detention is an unlawful retaliation against his activism and violates his constitutional rights.

events.summary: The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) announced the extension of an information collection requirement under OMB control number 1652-0002. This extension involves airport operators submitting data to TSA to ensure compliance with security provisions under 49 CFR part 1542. The information collection includes developing and implementing Airport Security Programs, conducting criminal history checks, and submitting identifying information for Security Threat Assessments. The estimated annual burden is 2,142,174 hours for 435 respondents.

events.summary: The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) issued correcting amendments to its rules regarding the 5.850-5.925 GHz band. The corrections address errors in the regulatory text published on December 13, 2024, which inadvertently included a non-existent rule section. The amendments remove § 90.394 from 47 CFR Part 90, effective March 21, 2025.
events.title: FCC Corrects Errors in 5.850-5.925 GHz Band Regulations
events.why_relevant: This correction ensures the accuracy and integrity of the FCC's regulatory framework, which is crucial for maintaining effective communication standards and compliance.

events.summary: The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) has submitted an information collection request to the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) for review. This request, under OMB Control Number 3060-0174, seeks to revise current information collection requirements related to sponsorship identification for broadcast stations. The FCC aims to reduce paperwork burdens, particularly for small businesses, while ensuring compliance with foreign sponsorship identification rules. Public comments are invited until April 21, 2025.
events.title: FCC Submits Information Collection for OMB Review
events.why_relevant: This action affects regulatory compliance and transparency in broadcasting, impacting how foreign sponsorships are disclosed to the public.

events.summary: The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has announced the facility fee rates for the Over-the-Counter (OTC) Monograph Drug User Fee Program for fiscal year 2025. The fees, effective from October 1, 2024, to September 30, 2025, are set at $37,556 for Monograph Drug Facilities (MDF) and $25,037 for Contract Manufacturing Organization (CMO) facilities. These fees support FDA's activities related to OTC monograph drugs and are due by June 2, 2025.
events.title: FDA Announces FY 2025 OTC Monograph Drug Facility Fee Rates
events.why_relevant: This announcement impacts the financial obligations of OTC drug manufacturers, influencing the regulatory landscape and economic conditions of the pharmaceutical industry.
